economic_context.details: Dispute over son Lambert leaving service without completing term, resulting in witness refusing to pay wages. Multiple disputes over trespassing animals on accused's 'meix' (enclosed land). Accused and husband made threatening remarks about those who had prosperity losing it. Marie femme de Jean Derechee claimed losses amounted to more than 200 francs. Witness Jean Ferry's wife had a bad leg, adding to economic hardship. Accused had 3 children in Allemagne (Germany), suggesting family economic migration. Jean Ferry accused of economizing by feeding animals straw instead of hay.

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial shows extensive reputation evidence spanning decades, with multiple witnesses reporting similar patterns (quarrels followed by animal deaths/illnesses). Notable that accused remained steadfast under torture and was ultimately released. Mother's prior reputation as witch established family pattern. Economic tensions evident in wage disputes, property boundary conflicts, and claimed losses of 200+ francs. Accused fled temporarily to daughter in val d'Orbey before arrest. Procureur général was C.M. Remy (Nicolas Rémy, author of Daemonolatria). Healing practice: accused gave advice about anise seeds for sick calves, but this appears more like folk veterinary knowledge than formal healing practice, so marked practiced_healing as false. The neuvaine (novena) to Beau Bernard represents counter-magic/religious remedy used by community. Economic status assessed as 'poor' based on: multiple children migrated to Germany for work, disputes over small amounts (wages, straw vs hay), and general village context. Plague mentioned as reason son left service. Zabillon was initially afraid to move to Vicq because of Claudatte's reputation. Child illness recovery was attributed to religious offering at Beau Bernard shrine after Claudatte came to buy pigs (possibly interpreted as her removing curse). Most witnesses report reputation spanning many years (12-60 years).
